subject: Re: [junit] RE: Why doesn't JUnit count asserts?
msgSnippet: That s an interesting point, Kevin. I suppose I m accustomed to a certain interpretation of a JUnit unit test. That interpretation is, If I can get to line X,
messageBody:
That's an interesting point, Kevin. I suppose I'm accustomed to a certain
interpretation of a JUnit unit test. That interpretation is, "If I can get
to line X, then nothing has gone wrong so far." For that reason,
"assertTrue(true)" doesn't speak to me -- it's the same as a blank line.

I would argue that using the identifier "success" communicates more
precisely than "assertTrue(true)", however. The latter can be written
anywhere to mean anything; however, the former can only mean "the test was
successful," otherwise don't call it "success". :)

Did the test not perfectly reveal my intentions as written?

While it's true that more detail can better reveal the coder's intentions,
don't conclude that one must always provide that detail in all situations.
That generally leads to someone else wondering if the additional redundant
detail is somehow significant. "If it weren't," he thinks, "then it
wouldn't be here. It must mean something..." In the end, it leads to more
confusion than it saves.

But this discussion starts to go beyond the scope of unit tests, so let's
not get too far down the path in public... :)

rainsber@... wrote: The following test case has no assertions...

public void testIllegalArgumentException() {
    try {
        MyClass myClass = new MyClass(null);
        fail("Created myClass with null argument.");
    }
    catch (IllegalArgumentException success) {
    }
}

...should I be worried that this test isn't good enough?I find that asserts
improve the readability of the test and can be used to document the
tester's intentions.

Cheers,
